bibl.note: 1863 July 16 Southgate Cregmile in Decher Station, Tenn., to his brother Crittenden. Continuous rain was the highlight on the trek from Murfreesboro. Not much action now that Bragg's Confederate forces are so far out of range; however, deserters continue to flood the camp by the hundreds with many more lying in wait to do the same. With Brig. Gen. Rosencrans's reputation as a commander and the presence of numerous mounted infantry seven shooters, under Gen. Turchin's command; retreat by both Bragg's and Morgan's forces continues to increase. Payday nears. Write soon.

div.p: I receved your welcolm letter but had no chance to rite on till to day.
we have had fine weather sence we have been here - but it rained most every day and night sence we left Murfreesboro I never saw as much rain as there has been this time of the year be four.
our army is on a stand still and I doent see any sines of us moving on for Bragg has got so far a head the we will never
catch up with him a gain. there are derserters coming in by the hundred every day and say the Acoun tings is full of them a frade to come in.
when we were fighting at Hovers Gap Bragg tolde his men when thay come on to our five and seven shoters for to lite out. so thay done it.

I hearde that olde morgan has been up though Indiana and Ohio if he is that will wake the people up if any thing will. he knows better than to fool Round old Rosey now we have to many mounted Infentry of seven shoters
for him now and Gen turchin in command.
Company E has sixteen Comishions and Non Comishion Ofisers and fifteen privets we are a going to be pade of for four months in a few days
I havend time to rite any more this time
